lexUnit.name: merge.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to be combined into one

sentence.text: Miyazaki 's attorney 's defence of his warped client was that , for Miyazaki , video and reality had merged ; he could n't tell gory fact from gory fiction .
These two problems may merge to produce even greater difficulties for prospective councillors .
All these diverse atmospheres merge together beautifully to create a most delightful and unique East Lindsey market town .
Dublin 's brand of rock music merges at times with traditional music , and the studios are used for both styles .
Deep rose merged with the turquoise and aquamarine of fast-fading night .
In 1925 the Disabled Society merged with the British Legion .
She 'd have just merged into the background .
She did n't notice Miguel Rafaelo watching her until her slight form merged into the darkness .
It was as if he no longer existed : he had already merged into their grey landscape , claimed by the marshes , the mud , the rocks and the waves .
For some , Saturday and Sunday merged into one , but the rest of us managed some well earned and undisturbed sleep .
This merged in 1927 with fellow East End brewers Taylor Walker of Limehouse .
The columns were to merge in the Hammersmith Road at 6.30 , an hour and a half before the rally .
Then on Sunday night all styles will merge in a monumental jam session .
The strands merge in the study of complete systems ( human and computer ) that carry out various linguistic tasks .
Already the information manager and the archivist are beginning to merge in a variety of business and government locations .
Thinking of Liz and Anna could n't wipe out those memories ; the memories merged in ways he did n't dare to face .
Sometimes it poured down in such thick sheets of water that earth and sky seemed merged in one grey wetness
